abstract: Compared with its better-known Vesuvian neighbor, Pompeii—where local officials, constrained by inadequate and mismanaged government funds, have long struggled in their efforts to conserve and protect the sprawling open-air site—Herculaneum has become a textbook case of successful archaeological conservation.
lead_paragraph: Compared with its better-known Vesuvian neighbor, Pompeii—where local officials, constrained by inadequate and mismanaged government funds, have long struggled in their efforts to conserve and protect the sprawling open-air site—Herculaneum has become a textbook case of successful archaeological conservation.

headline.main: Herculaneum’s Ruins Are Revived by Philanthropy
